page.title: 17Lundy's Past.
page.content: There are numerous-though largely unspectacular-remains on Lundy which provide very tangible evidence of the island's long and chequered past.These remains range from well preserved hut circles of the Bronze Age to the remains of several planes from World WarII. Evidence has been found of Stone Age peoples-but there are no signs of settlement before the Bronze Age.Some inscribed stones and pottery provide evidence of occupation in the Dark Ages.Lundy was known to the Vikings and the name Lundy derives from the Norse for Puffin Island. The Norman de Newmarch family held the island from around 1140 to 1150.Then the Mariscos took over and an era began which included rebellion and piracy.The island was held illegally and fines... {(continued)
